options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Have the courage to make important decisions

options.label: D

title: How do you know whom to trust? - Ram Neta

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary basis for most of our beliefs, according to the text?

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We would have more time to observe the world

options.label: D
options.text: We would have more opportunities to ask experts

options.label: C
options.text: They can only turn out to be wrong due to dishonesty

options.text: They can never turn out to be wrong

options.label: B
options.text: Their track record on a particular topic

options.label: A
options.text: Our track record of successes and failures

options.text: Our track record on a particular topic

options.label: B
options.text: To determine their level of honesty

options.label: C
options.text: To determine whether we can safely trust their testimony

options.label: D
options.text: To determine their level of education

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: We will always trust our instincts

options.label: B
options.text: We will never trust our instincts

options.label: C
options.text: We will have an objective view of ourselves and the world around us

options.label: D
options.text: We will have a subjective view of ourselves and the world around us

options.label: B

title: Pool medical patents, save lives - Ellen 't Hoen

multiple-choice.question: In the early 20th century, the Wright brothers successfully made an airplane fly, but their patent was not the only one in the industry. What was the result of this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a surge in innovation and the development of new aircraft.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to patent wars and a delay in the production of military airplanes.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the Wright brothers being forced to license their patent to others.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the aviation industry.

multiple-choice.question: In 2002, Nelson Obama, a Kenyan social scientist, was diagnosed with HIV and needed access to treatment. What was the initial response he received?

options.label: A
options.text: He was told that a cure existed and was available immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: He was told that treatment was not offered, but a cure was being researched.

options.label: C
options.text: He was told that a cure did not exist, and treatment was not available.

options.label: D
options.text: He was told that he needed to wait for further research before treatment could be considered.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the high cost of ARVs in 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: The cost of production was high due to the complexity of the medication.

options.label: B
options.text: The patents on the drugs were held by Western pharmaceutical companies that were not willing to make them available to others.

options.label: C
options.text: The demand for the medication was high, leading to a shortage and increased prices.

options.label: D
options.text: The government was not providing sufficient funding for the development of the medication.

multiple-choice.question: Which countries were able to produce generic versions of ARVs and make them available in the developing world?

options.label: A
options.text: The United States, Canada, and Europe.

options.label: D
options.text: D: Brazil and other South American countries.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the decrease in the price of ARVs?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of people with access to treatment decreased.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of people with access to treatment increased.

options.label: C
options.text: The price of treatment remained the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current situation regarding the availability of ARVs in developing countries?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of people with access to treatment has decreased.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of people with access to treatment has increased, but there are still challenges to be addressed.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of people with access to treatment has remained the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The quality of treatment has decreased.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge facing the development of new ARVs?

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of funding for research and development.

options.label: D
options.text: The patent landscape, which can scare generic manufacturers away, and the unwillingness of pharmaceutical companies to license their patents.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Medicines Patent Pool?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the cost of ARVs.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the availability of ARVs.

options.label: C
options.text: To make ARVs available to developing countries at a lower cost.

options.label: D
options.text: To promote the development of new ARVs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between the airplane patent pool and the Medicines Patent Pool?

options.label: A
options.text: The airplane patent pool was voluntary, while the Medicines Patent Pool is mandatory.

options.label: B
options.text: The airplane patent pool was mandatory, while the Medicines Patent Pool is voluntary.

options.label: C
options.text: The airplane patent pool was established to promote the development of new aircraft, while the Medicines Patent Pool is established to make ARVs available to developing countries.

options.label: D
options.text: The airplane patent pool was established to decrease the cost of ARVs, while the Medicines Patent Pool is established to increase the availability of ARVs.

multiple-choice.question: What is Nelson Obama's current situation regarding access to ARVs?

options.label: A
options.text: He is still waiting for treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: He has access to ARVs, but his son does not.

options.label: C
options.text: C: He is a member of the expert advisory group of the medicines patent pool and his son will soon be 14 years old and he has access to ARVs.

What is the name of the mite that is believed to have contributed to the decline of honeybee populations?
What is the name of the company that delivers, installs, and manages honeybee hives for individuals and businesses?

What is the term for the nutritional substitute for regular sugar that is made from honey?
What is the name of the city that has been a model for urban beekeeping with hives on the rooftop of their opera house?
What is the term for the process of trying to make honeybees healthier before they get sick by bringing them to areas where they are thriving?
What is the primary cause of Colony Collapse Disorder (CCD)?
What is the name of the researcher who has been studying honeybee health and developing ways to make bees healthier?

title: A future beyond traffic gridlock - Bill Ford

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial concern about the auto industry when they first started working at Ford Motor Company?

options.label: B
options.text: How to make cars more environmentally friendly

options.label: C
options.text: How to sell more cars and trucks

options.label: D
options.text: How to make cars more affordable

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience with their great-grandfather Henry Ford's mission for the Ford Motor Company?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker was never interested in the company's mission

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker disagreed with the company's mission

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker grew up with the company's mission and believed in it

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker was influenced by the company's mission

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge facing the world's transportation system according to the speaker?

options.label: B
options.text: The growing number of cars on the road

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of roads and infrastructure

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential solution to the speaker suggests to address the problem of global gridlock?

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a global network of interconnected solutions

options.label: C
options.text: Using alternative modes of transportation such as bicycles and walking

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the number of cars on the road

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the city in Abu Dhabi that is testing a system of driverless electric vehicles?
What is the expected impact of the growing number of cars on the road on the daily lives of people, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced traffic congestion and lower emissions

options.label: B
options.text: Increased traffic congestion and higher emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of a connected car network according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced emissions and improved air quality

options.label: B
options.text: Increased fuel efficiency and reduced traffic congestion

options.label: C
options.text: Improved navigation and reduced parking time

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for the future of personal mobility?

options.label: A
options.text: A future with zero emissions and freedom to move around the world

options.label: B
options.text: A future with increased traffic congestion and higher emissions

options.label: C
options.text: A future with reduced mobility and increased reliance on public transportation

options.label: D
options.text: A future with no change in the current transportation system

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action for the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new technologies to solve the problem of global gridlock

options.label: B
options.text: To invest in alternative modes of transportation such as bicycles and walking

options.label: C
options.text: To create a global network of interconnected solutions to solve the problem of global gridlock

options.label: D
options.text: To get out there and seek out solutions to the problem of global gridlock

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience about the importance of solving the problem of global gridlock?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not a significant problem and can be ignored

options.label: B
options.text: It is a complex problem that requires a global effort to solve

options.label: C
options.text: It is a problem that can be solved by one person or group

options.label: D
options.text: It is a problem that will solve itself over time
